title: On the Design of Weakly Coupled Crossed Ridge Gap Waveguides With Over 3:1 Bandwidth Ratio
authors: Davood Zarifi, Ali Sabbaghi Saber, Ali Farahbakhsh, Michal Mrozowski
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents an ultrawideband weakly coupled directional coupler based on ridge gap waveguide technology, addressing fabrication challenges at high frequencies. The proposed design strikes a balance between compactness, broad bandwidth, and manufacturability. To validate the concept and performance, a 30-dB coupler prototype is fabricated and measured. In addition, an innovative ultrawideband transition from ridge gap waveguide to coaxial line is introduced to ensure efficient excitation over the desired frequency band. Measurements confirm that the coupler achieves an exceptional fractional bandwidth exceeding 107% within the 12–40-GHz range. Experimental results indicate that the coupler maintains a return loss (RL) greater than 13dB and exhibits directivity exceeding 15dB, while achieving the coupling levels of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$31.5~\pm ~1.2$</tex-math> </inline-formula>dB over the full Ku-, K-, and Ka-bands. Compared to similar couplers, the proposed design exhibits remarkable properties, including an ultrawide bandwidth, compact size, stable coupling value, and low insertion loss (IL). These results demonstrate that the proposed gap waveguide-based weakly coupled directional coupler is well-suited for a large variety of broadband microwave and millimeter-wave (mmWave) applications.

title: An Intelligent Infusion Monitoring System with Capacitively Coupled Contactless Conductivity Detection-based Dual Sensing Capabilities_supp3-3665960.pdf
authors: Weiwen Liu
abstract: Intelligent monitoring of intravenous (IV) infusion is of great significance for reducing the workload of medical staff and ensuring patient treatment safety. Existing techniques often focus on single parameters and may pose contamination risks. We propose an intelligent infusion monitoring system with capacitively coupled contactless conductivity detection-based (C<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup>D-based) dual sensing capabilities. The proposed system innovatively extends C⁴D to impedance detection for infusion monitoring and features: 1) Safe and contamination-free: The contactless C<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup>D sensing technique eliminates the risk of drug contamination; 2) Dual-parameter measurement: By integrating a symmetric electrode drip rate sensor and a semi-circular tubular electrode identification sensor, it simultaneously achieves drip rate monitoring (15-60 drops/min with an error < ±1 drops/min) and solution type identification (100% differentiation among 16 standard KCl solutions and clinically common infusion types); 3) Multi-terminal collaborative monitoring: Through the STM32 main controller and 433 MHz wireless transmission, real-time data sharing and remote management are realized across bedside devices, mobile terminals, and PC terminals. All these demonstrate that the system not only addresses the limitations of traditional infusion monitoring, such as single functionality and contamination risks from contact-based measurements, but also provides an efficient and intelligent solution for clinical care, offering significant application value in improving medical quality and optimizing nursing workflows.

title: Efficient SoC Power Estimation With Machine Learning
authors: Sujay Pandit, Sujit Dey, Anand Raghunathan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: We propose machine learning (ML) power, the first ML-based framework that: 1) accelerates end-to-end RTL power estimation by addressing both its key bottlenecks—RTL simulation and power-model evaluation—and 2) extends ML-based power models to system-on-chips (SoCs) with configurable intellectual property (IP) blocks. ML-Power builds models that predict power versus time traces of each SoC block using a very small subset of internal signals called power proxies. The framework is composed of three components: ML-based power proxy activity estimation (PACE), exploiting spatio-temporal correlations for power proxy selection and ML-based power model evaluation (SCOPE), and representative configuration selection using active learning (RECAL). PACE trains a sequence-to-sequence (seq2seq) ML model to translate a transaction-level execution trace into a cycle-level trace of the power proxy signals, allowing much faster simulation models to be used in place of RTL simulation. SCOPE selects power proxies and trains ML-based power models for each block within the SoC. RECAL enables ML-Power to handle SoCs with configurable intellectual property (IP) blocks by using active learning to select a small subset of representative configurations, which are then used to train a unified power model that generalizes across the entire design space. We evaluate ML-Power on an ARM SSE-300 SoC and two RISC-V-based SoCs. Compared to prior state-of-the-art ML-based power estimation frameworks, SCOPE trains power models <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sim 65\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> faster, picks 40% fewer proxies, and achieves 2% lower estimation error. For the two RISC-V SoCs with configurable IP blocks, ML-Power achieves less than 10% error in per-cycle power across the entire design space using only 10–14 training configurations. ML-Power also achieves <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sim 300\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> inference-time speedup over a commercial RTL power estimation tool with less than 7% error in per-cycle power estimates.

title: Full-Duplex Cooperative Rate-Splitting and Precoding for Finite Blocklength Transmission
authors: Yu Du, Tiantian Li, Zimeng Li, Jie Tian, Jingping Qiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: Ultra-reliable and low-latency communications (URLLC) are crucial for the ever-emerging applications with mission-critical requirements. How to reduce the transmission latency and improve the transmission reliability is challenging for the future network design. To achieve this, we propose a full-duplex (FD) cooperative rate-splitting and precoding design for finite blocklength transmission in downlink URLLC systems. Adopting FD mode can make full utilization of the time resources, and rate-splitting can manage the inter-user interference flexibly by splitting the original message into the common and private parts. A typical scenario is considered where the relay user has the ability of simultaneous information reception and common stream forwarding. We formulate a transmission power minimization problem to jointly optimize the beamformers, the rate-splitting factors and the transmission power of relay user while meeting the URLLC requirements. To solve the non-convex problem, we propose an effective iterative method. Simulation results confirm the superiority of the proposed scheme compared with other baseline schemes, benefiting from the cooperation gain and the interference management ability of rate-splitting.

title: Optimization of Sensing Coverage and Resource Efficiency in ISAC Systems
authors: Yunfei Xi, Lifang Cao, Wei Deng, Liang Liu, Li Zhang, Wenzhi Li, Boyang Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) has become a key enabler for ubiquitous sensing in 5G-Advanced (5G-A) and 6G wireless networks, where a significant use case is the high-reliability drone detection in urban low-altitude airspace. While ISAC base stations (BSs) enable continuous aerial coverage through scalable networking, existing implementations exhibit severe resource inefficiencies: (1) Single beam-position coverage (beyond 1 km altitude) greatly exceeds most drone activities (below 300 m altitude), leading to significant energy waste in upper aerial beam positions. (2) Conventional designs optimized for maximum sensing coverage result in excessive resource redundancy in dense urban deployments, since the intersite distances of the BSs are typically reduced to 30-50% below the theoretical maximum coverage to mitigate building blockages. In this paper, we propose a new framework for optimizing the sensing coverage and resource efficiency of the ISAC systems. We first present an air interface design consisting of hybrid waveform and new frame structure. Moreover, we propose a novel coverage optimization scheme based on link budget analysis, including non-uniform sensing symbol allocation and adaptive pulse reception window. Simulation results demonstrate a 33% reduction in computational overhead with proportional interference suppression, while delivering 6 dB coherent integration gain for prioritized beam position.

title: Energy Efficient Tradeoff Scheme for UAV-Assisted Wireless Sensor Network Data Collection
authors: Hailong Tian, Xiangdong Jia, Wenyan Liang, Hongli Bao
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: With the development of communication technology, the Internet of Things (IoT) is playing an increasingly important role in real life, and the application of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) communication in IoT has also been widely studied. This work presents a data-collection scheme. Based on the UAV trajectory designing and the scheduling strategy for Sensor Nodes(SNs), a weighted maximization model of energy efficiency is constructed to maximize the weighted sum of energy efficiency, which is a mixed-integer nonlinear problem that is usually difficult to solve directly. Firstly, we decomposes the problem into three sub-problems and the lower bounds of the UAV trajectory were found by applying the first-order Taylor expansion. Then, a joint optimization algorithm based on Block Coordinate Descent (BCD) and Successive Convex Approximation (SCA) is proposed to obtain a local optimal solution that satisfies the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) condition. From the simulation results, it can be seen that the effective balance between the transmission rate and the energy consumption of the sensor nodes is realized, which demonstrates the feasibility of the proposed scheme.

title: Multi-Site MRI Harmonization via Content-Style Disentanglement
authors: Weitong Guo, Xiaodan Chen, Yumei Duan, Fuchao Cheng, Dekun Hu, Chang Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Data Science and Intelligent Systems (DSIS)
abstract: Multi-site magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies are significantly affected by site-specific biases arising from variations in scanners and imaging protocols across different sites, severely compromising the cross-site generalizability of deep learning models. To address this issue, this paper introduces a content-style disentanglement-based harmonization method for multi-site MRI data, which employs separate content and style encoders to disentangle anatomical content information from site-specific stylistic features. Furthermore, a Triplet Attention mechanism is integrated into the bottleneck layer of the content encoder to enhance the modeling of multidimensional dependencies within complex content structures. Experimental results on the IXI dataset demonstrate that, compared to baseline methods, our model achieves a 18.3% improvement in PSNR, a 13.3% increase in SSIM, and a 56.2% reduction in MSE on the HH-to-Guys harmonization task. It also exhibits consistently superior performance on the IOP-to-Guys harmonization task. Meanwhile, site classification experiments show that the SVM classification accuracy decreases from 90.0% to 48.3% after harmonization, indicating the effective removal of site-specific characteristics. Qualitative and quantitative results demonstrate that the proposed method successfully eliminates site-related biases while preserving fine anatomical structural details, offering an effective data harmonization solution for multi-site MRI studies.

title: Conventional Zero-Shot Learning with Semantic Graph-Enriched Non-Adversarial Synthetic Features
authors: Md Shakil Ahamed Shohag, Q. M. Jonathan Wu, Farhad Pourpanah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Data Science and Intelligent Systems (DSIS)
abstract: Adversarial training-based generative methods have shown strong performance in Zero-Shot Learning (ZSL), but they often come with significant drawbacks — including training instability and high computational cost. These approaches typically use the same feature generation pipeline for both Conventional ZSL (CZSL), where test classes are strictly unseen, and Generalized ZSL (GZSL), where both seen and unseen classes are present during inference. In this work, we argue that such frameworks are unnecessarily expensive for CZSL setups, where the primary objective is accurate recognition of unseen classes. We propose CZSL-SGNSF, a non-adversarial generative method that synthesizes unseen visual features and further enhances them through semantic graph propagation by enabling knowledge transfers across related unseen categories. For classification, we introduce a classifier trained jointly with cross-entropy and KL-divergence objectives on visual-semantic contrast. Extensive experiments on SUN, AwA2, and CUB demonstrate that our approach surpasses state-of-the-art adversarial methods in CZSL performance with significantly lower computational overhead for feature synthesis, while achieving promising results in both CZSL and GZSL compared to non-adversarial methods.

title: MOEVIL: Poisoning Experts to Compromise the Safety of Mixture-of-Experts LLMs
authors: Jaehan Kim, Seung Ho Na, Minkyoo Song, Seungwon Shin, Sooel Son
publish: 2025 IEEE Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC)
abstract: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) has emerged as a prominent architecture for scaling large language models (LLMs). In particular, leveraging readily available fine-tuned LLMs as experts provides an efficient and flexible approach to developing MoE LLMs. However, integrating highly capable but untrustworthy LLMs into an MoE system poses a significant safety risk, potentially compromising the overall safety of the MoE LLM system. To date, no study has explored how adversaries compromise an MoE LLM service by introducing a poisoned expert LLM. In this paper, we introduce MOEVIL, a novel expert poisoning attack designed to compromise the safety of MoE LLMs. We address the dissipation of harmful effects from a target expert within MoE systems by conducting harmful preference learning. Next, we strategically manipulate this expert's latent vector to deceive the gating networks. This manipulation indirectly steers routing decisions toward the poisoned expert when generating responses to harmful queries. MOEVIL demonstrates strong attack performance across diverse MoE configurations based on both Llama and Qwen LLMs, even when poisoning only a single expert. MOEVIL increases the harmfulness score from 0.58 to 79.42 in a Llama-based MoE LLM, outperforming existing harmful poisoning attacks. Furthermore, our results demonstrate that even safety alignment, when combined with an efficient MoE training strategy, fails to fully mitigate these risks. Our findings demonstrate the significant threat posed by harmful experts in MoE systems, underscoring the need for robust safety measures in MoE-based LLM development. Our implementation is available at https://github.com/jaehanwork/MoEvil.

title: Surface Treatment for Wafer Bonding Using Atmospheric Water Vapor Plasma Technology
authors: Wonyoung Choi, Seokjun Lee, Jungshin Lee, Wonuk Yoon, Youngjoo Lee, Seungho Hahn, Minwoo Rhee, Kwangjin Moon, Sangjin Hyun
abstract: The node scaling of semiconductor devices is facing technological limits, leading to increased attention on vertical stacking techniques such as wafer or die stacking. In particular, hybrid copper bonding (HCB) has gained significant interest due to its advantages of small form factor and high performance. To ensure high-quality bonding strength (B/S), it is necessary to form - OH on the bonding dielectric layer (SiO_<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, SiN, SiCN, etc). At the same time, CuOx formation on the HCB bonding surface should be suppressed for the effective electrical interconnection. We experimented SiCN-SiCN bonding in atmospheric plasma treatment, achieving a bonding strength of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.11 ~\mathrm{J} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>, and confirmed that at this level, there is CuOx de-oxidation effect of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-1.5 \AA$</tex>. In this paper, a new surface treatment process using vapor plasma at atmospheric pressure is proposed for HCB.

title: Reliability Evaluations of Pb-Free Solder Joint Formed Using Sn-Ag-Cu Solder Ball and Sn-Bi-Ag Solder Paste
authors: Jahyeon Kim, Taeyoon Im, Sojeong Lee, Won Bin Im, Yong-Ho Ko
abstract: Sn-3.0Ag-0.5Cu (SAC305) Pb-free solder has been widely used in electronic packaging for its excellent mechanical and electrical properties. However, its relatively high melting temperature (217° C) can induce substrate warpage and reliability during bonding processes. To solve this, low-temperature P b-free solders with S n - B i based lower bonding temperature have been gotten attentions. However, They have a fatal weakness with the brittleness of Bi which can degrade properties of solder joints. Therefore, we studied a combined solder joint with SAC305 solder ball and Sn-57Bi-1Ag solder paste using various bonding methods. We also researched joint properties, such as the Bi diffusion and intermetallic compound (IMC) thickness, and the shear strength during isothermal aging to improve solder joint reliability.

title: SVPrompt-MR: An LLM-Based Metamorphic Relation Identification Method with Self-Verification Mechanism
authors: Jun Huang, Meng Li, Xiaohua Yang, Jie Liu, Shiyu Yan
abstract: Metamorphic testing is an effective technique to alleviate the oracle problem in software testing, with metamorphic relations (MRs) as its core. Currently, the identification of MRs relies mainly on domain experts, which leads to low efficiency and considerable subjectivity in MR formulation. Large Language Models (LLMs) show great potential for identifying MRs automatically. In this paper, we propose a self-verificationbased prompt construction strategy for MR identification, which consists of two stages: MR identification and MR verification. Our method is applied to the thermal-hydraulic safety design program for pebble-bed high-temperature gas-cooled reactors, with deepseek-R1 as the underlying model. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach not only covers all 44 MRs identified by experts, but also discovers 24 new MRs. It significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of coverage rate, accuracy rate, and innovation rate, thereby exhibiting superior identification capability. The research results not only advance the study of MR identification, but also provide a valuable reference and inspiration for researchers.

title: MSPM: A Multi-Strategy Prompting Method for Goal-Oriented Modeling from User Stories
authors: Yi Wang, Chunhui Wang, Ye Zhai, Tong Li, Zhiguo Liu
abstract: In agile development, user stories are used to express user requirements, which employ simple natural language sentences. As software scales grow and evolve continuously, managing user stories becomes increasingly challenging, necessitating the modeling of user stories to clarify their associated semantics. Currently, representing user stories as goal models is an effective approach. However, extracting the semantics of the goal models from user stories is a time-consuming and labor-intensive task. In particular, abstracting low-level user stories into high-level goals remains difficult and relies heavily on the expertise of requirements engineers. This paper leverages the knowledge extraction and comprehension capabilities of large language models (LLMs) to divide the goal model extraction task into two categories: explicit concept extraction and implicit concept extraction. This classification is based on direct extraction from the user story field (explicit) and extraction according to implicit semantics (implicit). A multi-strategy prompting method (MSPM) is devised, which combines prompt templates, few-shot learning, ReAct, and chain-of-thought techniques to suit explicit and implicit goal model concept extraction, ultimately generating iStar models. The experimental results show that the proposed method has an average F 1 scores of 97.9% and 92.7% for the nodes and relationships in the extraction of the goal model, and has advantages in the completeness of the extraction of the goal modeling element.

title: APILOT: Improving the Security and Usability of LLM Code Suggestions via Outdated API Mitigation
authors: Weiheng Bai, Keyang Xuan, Pengxiang Huang, Qiushi Wu, Jianing Wen, Jingjing Wu, Kangjie Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC)
abstract: With the rapid development of large language models (LLMs), their applications have expanded into diverse fields, such as code assistance. However, the substantial size of LLMs makes their training highly resource- and time-consuming, which leads to lengthy retraining and delayed updating. Consequently, LLMs trained based on old data may generate outdated results. This becomes extremely critical in the scenario of avoiding vulnerabilities. New vulnerabilities are discovered every day. Without updating their knowledge, LLMs may inadvertently generate code that includes these newly discovered vulnerabilities. Current strategies, such as prompt engineering and fine-tuning, do not effectively address this issue. Prompt engineering fails to equip LLMs with comprehensive, up-to-date knowledge, while fine-tuning remains prohibitively resource-intensive and time-consuming. To address this issue, we study the problem of LLM recommending outdated APIs and propose a new solution, named APILOT, which maintains a real-time, quickly updatable dataset of outdated APIs. Additionally, APILOT utilizes pre-constructed cache prediction and augmented generation methods that leverage this dataset to navigate LLMs in generating secure, version-aware code. We conducted a comprehensive empirical evaluation of APILOT across seventeen state-of-the-art large language models (LLMs), including both open-source and commercial systems. The results demonstrate that APILOT reduces outdated API recommendations by an average of 75%, with some models achieving up to 100% mitigation in specific large language models. Notably, these improvements are achieved with minimal performance overhead. Interestingly, while enhancing security, APILOT also improves the usability of LLM -generated code by an average of 37%, with gains reaching up to 85.6% in certain large language models. Importantly, these improvements are achieved without compromising code functionality, as measured by ICE-SCORE evaluations across diverse prompts and LLMs. This demonstrates APILOT's dual benefit─it not only reduces the risk of outdated API usage but also enhances the practical utility and deployability of generated code. Together, these results highlight APILOT 's potential to improve both security and developer experience in real-world AI-assisted programming environments.

title: PIM-ORAM: Towards Oblivious RAM Primitives in Commodity Processing-In-Memory
authors: Byeongsu Woo, Kha Dinh Duy, Youngkwang Han, Brent Byunghoon Kang, Hojoon Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC)
abstract: Oblivious RAM (ORAM) is theoretically proven to render memory access patterns of a computation completely uniform, mitigating memory side-channel attacks. However, it is accompanied by orders of magnitude slower memory access latency and, thus, is often impractical in many circumstances. On the other hand, Processing-In-Memory (PIM) has been advancing as a solution to accelerate memory-intensive work-loads and mitigate the memory wall problem. In this paper, we explore the new direction of in-DRAM oblivious RAM with a design named PIM-ORAM. We retrofit the currently available commodity PIM hardware to provide future direction for secure computation on PIM, and design PIM-ORAM. Our design proposes split-data ORAM, a parallelizable in-memory ORAM scheme that takes full advantage of the parallel computing power of the PIM while retaining the original security guarantee of ORAM and dealing with the constraints existing in the commodity PIM. We evaluate PIM-ORAM using the PIM -enabled testbed cloud to provide more realistic numerical values. The evaluation shows that PIM-ORAM alleviates the increase of memory bus usage and ORAM access latency when the ORAM capacity increases.

title: Exploring the Role and Practice of Implementation Artificial Intelligence (AI) in ERP Systems: A Bibliometric and Systematic Literature Review
authors: Adelfin Farha Algiffari Panggabean, Hanny Juwitasary, Dima Yudhatama
publish: 2025 International Conference on ICT for Smart Society (ICISS)
abstract: The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) within Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems brings multiple benefits through enhanced business process automation and improved decision-making capabilities. Enabled by predictive analytics, machine learning, natural language processing, and automation technologies. This research explores AI integration in ERP systems potential opportunities and challenges by analyzing their effects on operational efficiency, forecasting capabilities, real-time insight and decision-making processes. The study performed a bibliometric and Systematic Literature Review (SLR) analysis to track research trends and understand keyword relationships. This research discusses the benefit in SCM, HR, PP, CRM, and sales modules. The advantages of AI-enhanced ERP systems exist alongside persistent challenges, including poor data quality, integration complexity, and organizational resistance to change. Research shows that AI can transform ERP systems, but overcoming integration challenges requires changes in both technology and organizational structure. Upcoming studies need to develop actionable guidance and structures that allow businesses to adopt AI-enhanced ERP systems in a scalable and sustainable manner.

title: Multi-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization for Dynamic Spectrum Access in Low-Altitude Intelligent Networks
authors: Jinlong Wu, Bin Qi, Wensheng Zhang, Jian Sun, Hengtai Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: A novel dynamic spectrum access (DSA) scheme based on the multi-agent proximal policy optimization (MAPPO) algorithm is proposed to accommodate the dynamic and complex spectrum environment in low-altitude intelligent networks (LAINs). In LAINs, the nodes have to meet required communication performance, such as large bandwidth, low latency, and high reliability under challenging spectrum usage situations with strong interference and high complexity. As a new deep reinforcement learning (DRL) method, MAPPO can provide an efficient DSA solution for distributed nodes in LAINs to address spectrum usage challenges. The key obstacles in using artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms to solve problems related to wireless communications are latency and convergence issues. In order to overcome these limitations, an adaptive sliding clip (ASC) mechanism is included in the MAPPO algorithm to enable faster and more stable convergence during the deployment phase. Simulation results indicate that MAPPO can outperform traditional DRL algorithms in solving the DSA problem within LAINs. Meanwhile, the ASC mechanism enables MAPPO to achieve enhanced adaptability in dynamic spectrum environments.

title: Developing in-House AI Using LSS Simulation and the BCGC Model: A Strategic Innovation Framework
authors: Zukra Budi Utama, Harjadi Harjono
publish: 2025 International Conference on ICT for Smart Society (ICISS)
abstract: The main idea in this study is the development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) independently within the company, through the Logic Simulation System (LSS) simulation approach of the Base Change Growth Control (BCGC) model for the implementation of company policies, in the concept of continuous innovation integration in preparation for future changes. This study explores the development of in-house Artificial Intelligence (AI) through the Logic Simulation System (LSS) and the Base Change Growth Control (BCGC) model. Through a case study of PT. Astra Component Indonesia, the research demonstrates how systematic innovation and policy simulation can result in dramatic organizational improvements-highlighted by a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20,000 \%$</tex> innovation growth in one year. The findings serve as a practical reference for industry-wide AI adoption aligned with sustainable development goals (SDG's) number 8 which will impact numbers <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1,2,3,9$</tex> as part of global synergy for a sustainable future.

title: Atmospheric Turbulence Prediction Based on Optimal Feature Extraction and Integrated Long Short-Term Memory Networks
authors: Peilin He, Zibo Zhuang
publish: 2026 6th International Conference on Consumer Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICCECE)
abstract: Turbulence poses a significant threat to aviation safety due to its sudden onset and irregular nature. Traditional prediction models often struggle to capture the complex nonlinear and multi-scale characteristics of turbulence. To address this issue, this paper develops a multi-step turbulence prediction framework that integrates wavelet decomposition with deep learning. The study is based on Doppler lidar wind field observation data from the approach airspace of Kashgar Airport in 2024, aiming to predict turbulence variations over the next fifteen minutes. The model first employs two-dimensional discrete wavelet transform to extract multi-scale time-frequency features from the wind speed matrices, and then uses correlation analysis to select key indicators, thereby enhancing the physical interpretability of the features. A hybrid deep learning framework is proposed by integrating a Transformer module for capturing global periodic patterns, a deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) for extracting local disturbance features, and a bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM) network for modeling bidirectional temporal dependencies. Experimental results show that the proposed fusion model consistently outperforms all the baseline models used for comparison in terms of EDR prediction accuracy, stability, and generalization capability.

title: AI-Powered Sensor Fusion and IoT Model for Mitigating Wildlife Threats in Agriculture
authors: N Prakash, Praveen, Sowmyaa, Sakthi Vinayakam, Tamilselvi, Boopathy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Computing, Information and Control Systems (ICOIICS)
abstract: Repeated wildlife intrusions pose a serious threat to agricultural productivity, resulting in significant crop losses, reduced yield quality, and financial distress for farmers. Conventional protection techniques such as physical fencing, manual surveillance, and sound-based deterrents are often ineffective due to their high labor demands and limited adaptability. To overcome these limitations, this study proposes an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven Internet of Things (IoT) framework utilizing multi-sensor data fusion for efficient wildlife detection and prevention. The proposed system integrates motion, acoustic, and thermal sensors to collect field data, which are analyzed using an AI-based classification algorithm to accurately identify animal activity and trigger suitable countermeasures. By enhancing detection accuracy, minimizing false alarms, and enabling predictive analytics, the model ensures proactive crop protection. Additionally, the incorporation of edge computing facilitates real-time data processing and rapid response, thereby improving the overall efficiency and adaptability of the system in dynamic agricultural environments. This intelligent, costeffective, and scalable solution contributes to the advancement of autonomous and sustainable smart farming practices.

title: Automatic Segmentation and Spatial Feature Extraction for Echogram Labeling in Acoustic Target Classification
authors: Sandi Wibowo, Fety Fitriyanti Lubis, Suhono Harso Supangkat
publish: 2025 International Conference on ICT for Smart Society (ICISS)
abstract: This study introduces an automated method for echogram segmentation and acoustic target labeling by integrating multi-level Otsu thresholding with spatial feature extraction. The method begins by transforming raw single frequency echosounder data into Sv matrices, followed by preprocessing that includes matrix rotation and NaN handling to preserve spatial fidelity. Initial segmentation is performed using three-class Otsu thresholding, which partitions acoustic intensities into substrate, intermediate, and background classes. These segmented masks are refined through morphological operations and hole-filling to eliminate noise. Subsequently, substrate class masks are used to detect seafloor boundaries, from which depth and distance-to-bottom maps are derived. This spatial context is then employed to redefine ecological labels—substrate, plankton, demersal, and pelagic—based on vertical structure and acoustic profile. The resulting labeled echograms are organized into fixed-size patches that match the input dimensions required for spatially aware deep learning models. Feature evaluations using PCA and LDA confirm the discriminative power of the spatial-acoustic representations across ecological classes. Performance-wise, the pipeline significantly reduces manual annotation effort, standardizes preprocessing across samples, and integrates class-balanced sampling to mitigate bias from dominant substrates or background regions. Overall, this framework enables scalable, consistent, and ecologically meaningful labeling of echogram datasets, supporting downstream applications in marine biomass estimation and habitat monitoring.

title: Research on the Design of Multi-Unit Power Take-Off System for Wave Energy Converter
authors: Yaqun Zhang, Guoyu Zhang, Zhaoji Lin, Zhenpeng Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: Large-scale wave energy power generation devices usually adopt hydraulic energy conversion systems. This paper takes the 500 kW wave energy power generation device as the research object, designs a multi-unit hydraulic energy conversion system, and conducts three-dimensional modeling of the system. In order to explore the influence of the selection of three key equipment, namely hydraulic cylinders, accumulators and motors, on the performance of the energy conversion system, numerical simulation experiments were carried out under the designed sea conditions to study the relationship between the motion amplitude of the hydraulic cylinder, the effective working area of the hydraulic cylinder, the capacity of the accumulator and the displacement of the motor and the system pressure, the total real-time power generation and the total power generation. Through the analysis and comparison of the simulation results of five sets of data for each type of equipment, it is obtained that the movement amplitude of the hydraulic cylinder is related to the maximum wave of the design working condition of the wave energy power generation device. It has a negative impact on the system pressure, the total real-time power generation, the total power generation, the effective working area of the hydraulic cylinder, and a positive impact on the accumulator capacity and motor displacement. The final selection of the hydraulic cylinder length is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3. 8}$</tex> meters, the effective working area of the hydraulic cylinder, the accumulator capacity is 500 liters, and the motor displacement is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$46 \text{ml} / \mathrm{r}$</tex>.

title: Frequency-Domain Anti-Interference Coding for Cognitive Spectrum-Division Transmission Systems
authors: Jun Yong, Chao Yang, Wei Ge, Guangwei Li, Jielin Fu, Lin Zheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: Interference resistance for broadband signals is critical for reliable transmission in complex electromagnetic environments and communication countermeasures. Cognitive spectrum-division transmission (SDT) provides an effective solution for such interference resistance by dividing broadband signals into sub-spectra transmitted over idle regions of the cognitive radio spectrum, effectively mitigating the impact of interference. However, interference may still occur in a few sub-spectra of the system, leading to increased bit error rate (BER). In this paper, a frequency-domain coding (FC) scheme is proposed to further enhance the resilience of SDT systems against interference by constructing structured redundant sub-spectra. To mitigate SNR loss, the encoding matrix is optimized. Moreover, the decoding method is developed in known and unknown interfered sub-spectra cases. Finally, simulation results show that the FC scheme significantly reduces BER degradation induced by interfered sub-spectra, outperforming recovery techniques based on time-domain error correction code.

title: Optimal UHF Sensor Placement for Partial Discharge Localization in Digital Twin Open-Space Substation
authors: Jun Qiang Chan, Wong Jee Keen Raymond, Hazlee Azil Illias, S. M. Kayser Azam, Mohamadariff Othman, Tze Mei Kuan
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd Student Conference on Research and Development (SCOReD)
abstract: Optimal sensor placement is critical for accurate partial discharge (PD) localization in open-air substations. This study investigates the impact of sensor arrangements on localization accuracy. Comparison between interior and exterior sensor array configurations using digital twin data had been made, employing iterative algorithms including Newton Iterative, Particle Swarm Optimization, Whale Optimization Algorithm, Ant Colony Optimization and Grey Wolf Optimization) for PD coordinate estimation. Results show that the optimized exterior sensor array arrangement achieves remarkable accuracy, with iterative algorithms yielding 0.06% average errors (near-zero absolute errors) across 36 test coordinates. These findings offer practical guidelines for field deployment and are adaptable to other applications such as PD localization in power transformers.

title: Fabrication of Parylene-Aluminum Redistribution Layer Interposer for Sensor Packaging Applications
authors: Imants Cirulis, Martin Kuehn, Carlos Rincon-Ruiz, Franz Selbmann, Uwe Zschenderlein, Silvia Braun, Bernhard Wunderle, Frank Roscher, Maik Wiemer, Harald Kuhn
abstract: Redistribution layer (RDL) interposers offer a platform for integrating multiple chiplets or integrated circuits within a single package. This technology utilizes fine metal lines and organic materials (polymers) to connect different areas within a chip or between chips. Organic thin films can serve as a more cost-effective alternative to glass and silicon-based interposers for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \mathrm{D} / 3 \mathrm{D}$</tex> chip integration. Polymers such as benzocyclobutene (BCB), polyimide (PI), and photosensitive polyimide (PSPI) are processed using the semi-additive process (SAP) for 2.5D integration. However, the process involves challenges like high curing temperature, 200° C to 400° C, and high CTE around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$60 \text{ppm} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>. Alongside these polymers, parylene could be a good candidate for a redistribution layer (RDL) interposer application. It has superior chemical inertness, sufficient thermal stability, low permeability, no shrinkage, and biocompatibility. Parylene is deposited in highly conformal layers at ambient temperature. It unites several advantageous functionalities for packaging, i.e., it can be used as an ultra-thin, flexible substrate, dielectric, encapsulation, as well as an adhesive bonding layer.

title: Enhancing GNN Learning on Relational Databases using Semantic Clustering-based Graph Enrichment
authors: Hwiseung Son, Kunyoung Kim, Donggyu Kim, Mye Sohn
publish: 2026 IEEE International Conference on Big Data and Smart Computing (BigComp)
abstract: Relational databases (RDBs) have been widely utilized for managing and analyzing large-scale business data. However, analyzing RDBs with machine learning techniques requires complex feature engineering, which can be time-consuming, error-prone, and prone to information loss. Recent research in relational deep learning (RDL) attempts to map RDB data to graph structures, enabling direct learning via Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). Despite these efforts, current methods face challenges such as long path lengths between semantically related nodes, which negatively affect model performance. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel graph enrichment method that integrates both primary key-foreign key (PK-FK) relationships and semantic information derived from textual descriptions in RDB records. The proposed method utilizes semantic clustering on textual data to generate additional nodes and their corresponding edges. This enriched graph is then incorporated into the GNN model, enhancing the propagation of relevant information by reducing path lengths between semantically related nodes. Furthermore, this paper introduces a weight-based adjustment mechanism for the additionally generated nodes to account for potential uncertainty in clustering results. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework improves the performance of GNNs compared to the RDL method.

title: Improving Cache Performance using a Learned Replacement Policy
authors: Bhukya Krishna Priya, Tarun Kumar Revelli, Desetti Rajesh
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology (CICT)
abstract: Cache replacement policies play a crucial role in determining the performance of modern processors by managing which cache line data is to be retained or evicted. The existing standard static replacement policies do not adapt to the dynamic nature of memory access patterns and the diversity of computer programs. This paper explores the application of Machine Learning (ML) to improve cache performance by learning access patterns and predicting optimal eviction candidates. The proposed methodology implements an XGBoost-based replacement policy in the ChampSim simulator, leveraging features such as memory addresses, program counters (PCs), access types, reuse distances, and temporal locality. The model is trained on trace data collected from cache operations, achieving 90% classification accuracy on held-out cache trace data in predicting eviction candidates. The performance of the XGBoost-based replacement policy is evaluated against standard replacement policies across multiple benchmarks from the SPEC CPU2017 suite. Key metrics such as Instructions Per Cycle (IPC) and cache hit rates are analyzed to assess improvements. Results demonstrate that the ML-driven policy can reduce cache misses and improve cache performance, particularly in workloads with irregular access patterns.

title: Autonomous Obstacle Avoidance System for Spider parallel robot Based on Deep learning visual Perception
authors: Yan Chen, Xingwen Gu, Mengdi Xia, Jiabao An, Xiaohui Li, Adi Zhao
publish: 2026 6th International Conference on Consumer Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICCECE)
abstract: Dynamic obstacle avoidance constitutes a critical component in enabling autonomous mobility and safe operation of robots. In complex and dynamically changing operational environments, robots must possess real-time obstacle detection and dynamic path planning capabilities. This study employs a spider parallel robot as the platform, integrating an RGB-D depth camera and an inertial measurement unit to construct an environmental perception system, thereby providing the robot with multimodal information such as three-dimensional visual data and attitude angles. Firstly, an enhanced object detection model, YOLOv4-M, is proposed based on YOLOv4. By incorporating an additional detection layer, introducing a spatial pyramid pooling structure, and optimizing anchor boxes using K-means clustering, the model improves the accuracy and robustness of multi-scale obstacle recognition. The model identifies and localizes obstacles within color images and employs depth map alignment techniques to determine obstacle dimensions and their spatial distances relative to the robot. Based on real-time robot attitude data and obstacle identification results, an improved artificial potential field-based obstacle avoidance decision-making model is developed. This model integrates a dead-zone distance mechanism and a dynamic steering strategy to effectively address local minima issues inherent in traditional potential field methods, thereby enabling dynamic walking path planning. The generated decision commands are transmitted to the robot's motion control unit, ultimately achieving autonomous obstacle avoidance in unknown environments. Both simulation and physical experiments validate that the proposed system effectively accomplishes autonomous obstacle avoidance tasks for the spider parallel robot. This research provides a technical foundation and reference for obstacle recognition and autonomous navigation in robots relying solely on visual and inertial sensors.

title: Human-in-the-Loop AI for Waste Segregation: Accuracy, Equity, and Pathways to Scale
authors: Vinod Patel, Margi Patel, Akash Bhasney, Anand Gadwal, Nitin Rathore, Ramesh Naik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Computing, Information and Control Systems (ICOIICS)
abstract: Human-in-the-loop (HIL) artificial intelligence has provided a viable way to implement waste-segregation systems in urban settings with high levels of noise and high variability. In this study, a socio-technical model is developed and tested in order to establish a relationship between data and governance factors and the adoption of HIL-AI segregation at scale. We assessed 9 reflective constructs: Data Quality, HIL Effectiveness, Perceived Accuracy, Explainability, Fairness & Equity, Trust, Perceived Scalability, Economic Viability, and Adoption Intention, using five-point Likert scales, on a crosssectional survey of 276 stakeholders in waste operations. Measurement and structural relations were measured using partial least squares structural equation modeling (SmartPLS; Mode A). Its measurement model exhibited high reliability and convergent validity (outer loadings were mostly above. 80, AVE was above. 70), moderate discriminant validity, and acceptable fit (SRMR was about 0.5). Perceived accuracy structurality Data Quality and HIL Effectiveness were the drivers of perceived accuracy, Trust was dominated by Explainability, then Fairness and Equity and Accuracy. The strongest explained factor was Adoption Intention, which was described by Economic Viability and Perceived Scalability, and Trust was considered a significant mediator; the direct effect between Accuracy to Adoption was also low and positive. The model described moderate variation in important outcomes (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R} 2=.36$</tex> in Accuracy;. 29 in Trust;. 46 in Adoption Intention). The results suggest that scale requires accuracy but not enough, which is the combination of qualities of governance, such as transparent reasoning, fair distribution of burden, and plausible unit economics that transform the technical performance into the organizational commitment. The research also offers an empirically supported framework and validated tool to those municipalities that wish to implement HIL-AI wastesegregation in accurate, fair, and scalable ways.

title: Fed-DCL: A Federated Dual-Continual Learning Framework for Adaptive Electric Power Load Forecasting Under Concept Drift
authors: Yueyang Gong, Bin Pan, Kai Lyu, Fenggang Sun, Peng Lan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: To address the non-stationarity and privacy protection challenges in electric power load forecasting, this paper proposes a Federated Dual-Continual Learning (Fed-DCL) framework. This method introduces drift detection and dual knowledge distillation mechanisms within the federated learning framework, enabling adaptive learning and knowledge retention for conceptual drift. Clients assess distribution change intensity via a drift detector and activate dual knowledge distillation mechanism during strong drift to fuse historical and global knowledge, effectively mitigating catastrophic forgetting. Servers employ a multi-factor adaptive weighted aggregation strategy while maintaining a global knowledge pool for cross-round knowledge sharing and accumulation. Experiments validate the framework across three scenarios-normal, abrupt, and gradual-using the Electricity Load Diagrams dataset. Results demonstrate that Fed-DCL outperforms existing methods in prediction accuracy, convergence stability, and adaptation speed, exhibiting superior robustness and adaptability particularly in abrupt and gradual mutation scenarios.

title: AI Agents in Healthcare: A Survey of Applications, Resources, and Challenges
authors: Sami Rashid, Md Fahim Shahriar, Sumaiya Karim Katha, Ezharuddin Jubaer, Akm Moshiur Rahman Mazumder, Ashraful Islam, Mohsena Ashraf, Asif Mahmud, M. Ashraful Amin
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd Student Conference on Research and Development (SCOReD)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have accelerated the emergence of agentic Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems in healthcare, representing a paradigm shift from static models to autonomous entities capable of complex medical reasoning. This survey examines AI agents across six domains: clinical decision support, healthcare systems management, clinical consultation, medical education, medical imaging, and evaluation frameworks. We analyze over 30 systems including MDAgents, Agent Hospital, ColaCare, and AgentClinic, identifying key architectural patterns and performance characteristics. These systems demonstrate promising results across a range of clinical tasks, leveraging both multi-agent collaboration and specialized medical reasoning. Critical deployment barriers include data privacy, algorithmic bias, regulatory gaps, safety concerns in multi-agent architectures, explainability requirements, and integration challenges. We identify open research problems and highlight key challenges to advancing safe, reliable, and impartial healthcare agentic AI.

title: Performance Analysis of FAS-Assisted RSMA Communication System
authors: Supriya Kumari, Vimal Bhatia, Keshav Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology (CICT)
abstract: Fluid antenna systems (FAS) have recently been recognized as a promising enabler for sixth-generation (6G) wireless communications, owing to their ability to dynamically adapt antenna positions within a confined region. Rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA), on the other hand, allows messages to be divided into common and private parts, which can significantly improve the user experience, especially in scenarios with diverse channel conditions. This advantage is particularly pronounced in FAS, where users can dynamically adjust their antennas for optimal performance. In this paper, we investigate the performance of a FAS-assisted RSMA communication system to utilize their synergistic benefits. We consider a scenario where a fixed base station (BS) transmits information to users equipped with a planar fluid antenna. We begin by deriving the joint cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the effective channel at the user by utilizing copula theory to model the correlation between the channel fading coefficients. To gain more insights, delay outage rate (DOR) is derived. Simulation results demonstrates that the integration of RSMA and FAS leads to improved overall system performance compared to conventional single-input single-output (SISO) RSMA systems. The analytical expressions derived are validated through simulation results.

title: Physics Informed TCN-eKAN for Aeroengine Rotor Anomaly Detection
authors: Mengyu Chen, Qin Meng, Zhengda Zhao, Junshen Chen, Xin Lu, Zechen Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Data Science and Intelligent Systems (DSIS)
abstract: As the core rotating component of an aeroengine, the rotor system directly determines the engine's reliability and flight safety. Therefore, it is crucial to adopt effective anomaly detection methods to monitor the rotor's operating condition. Typically, the vibration signal of the rotor is used as the key source of information for anomaly detection. However, fault data of aeroengine rotors under real operating conditions are extremely scarce, making it difficult to adequately train intelligent diagnostic models and thereby limiting the engineering application of rotor anomaly detection technology. In recent years, some studies have attempted to reduce the dependence on measured data by training models with a combination of simulated and measured data. However, significant differences in the information distribution between simulated and measured data lead to a substantial decline in the diagnostic accuracy of intelligent models. To address this issue, this paper proposes a Physics Informed Temporal Convolutional Network with efficient Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (PITCN-eKAN) for anomaly detection of aeroengine rotor systems. The proposed model obtains the theoretical response output of the actual data by constructing a mechanism simulation model, which is adopted as the physical constraint in the data-driven model training process. A network framework guided by physical information is constructed to improve the fitting accuracy of the deep learning model with the theoretical output, thus achieving high-precision anomaly detection. The PITCN-eKAN model provides a new concept for the engineering application of intelligent diagnostic algorithms for aeroengine rotors.

title: Sustainable Flexible Wearable Antenna Using Rubber Substrate for Wireless Body Area Networks
authors: Wan Mirza Liyana Wan Mazri, Sarah Yasmin Mohamad, Aiman Hakimi Rahimi, Norun Farihah Abdul Malek, Md. Rafiqul Islam, Mohamed Hadi Habaebi, Huda Adibah Mohd Ramli
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd Student Conference on Research and Development (SCOReD)
abstract: The growing demand for flexible antennas in the telecommunications industry has driven the need for compact designs with improved performance. Microstrip antennas are particularly attractive due to their low profile, ease of fabrication, and adaptability. A key challenge in enhancing flexible antennas lies in selecting a suitable substrate. In this work, rubber is proposed as an alternative substrate material because of its flexibility, conductivity, efficiency, ease of fabrication, and water resistance, making it suitable for Wireless Body Area Network (WBAN) applications. The proposed antenna operates at 2.4 GHz with a relative permittivity (εr) of 3.0, a frequency commonly used for wearable devices. Two antenna designs, rectangular and circular microstrip patches, were developed, simulated, and analyzed using CST Microwave Studio (CST-MWS). Performance metrics including reflection coefficient, VSWR, gain, directivity, and bandwidth were evaluated under flat and bent conditions of 15°, 30°, 45°, and 90°. Results show that both designs achieved satisfactory performance, demonstrating their robustness and suitability for WBAN applications.

title: Behdiffnet: A Hierarchical Diffusion Model for Behavior-Aware Network Traffic Generation
authors: Jiaqian Jiang, Ke Yu, Xiaofei Wu
publish: 2025 9th IEEE International Conference on Network Intelligence and Digital Content (IC-NIDC)
abstract: Network traffic data is vital for network optimization, security, and other fields, but high-quality real data is scarce due to privacy and commercial constraints, making high-fidelity synthetic traffic generation critical for research and applications. Existing traffic generation methods often struggle to capture dynamic user intent at the application level, suffering from limitations like mode collapse or oversimplified feature modeling. Rule-based and GAN-based approaches, for instance, struggle to capture the complex interplay of behavioral patterns and network protocols, leading to low controllability and realism. This paper proposes BehDiffNet, a two-stage hierarchical diffusion model for behavior-aware network traffic generation to address these challenges. The model employs a dual-conditional generation mechanism (behavioral sequence conditioning and protocol constraint conditioning): the upper layer models user intent at the application layer by embedding application order, frequency and temporal semantics in behavioral sequences, and re-generates them through diffusion models and protocol constraints, while the lower layer integrates conditional bootstrapping through a two-branch transformer. Utilizing adversarial training and cross-feature attention, the model effectively captures temporal dependencies and multidimensional feature correlations. Experiments demonstrate that the model is more advantageous in terms of statistical alignment and protocol consistency compared to the baseline.

title: Research on the Improvement of New Energy Incentive Policies Under the Electricity Marketization Reform
authors: Yunling Sun, Hongwei Li, Henan Wang, Lei Jiao, Jilong Wu, Yantong Liu, Ying Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: Promoting the high-quality development of new energy is an essential pathway to achieving China's dual carbon goals. Given the generation characteristics of wind- and solar-dominated new energy and the current stage of China's power system development, it is crucial to design rational and effective incentive policies for new energy. This paper examines the experiences and lessons of new energy incentive policies in the United Kingdom and the United States, and traces the evolution of China's policy framework, with particular attention to the Chinese style of the contract-for-difference (CfD) mechanism. Building on this foundation, the study conducts an in-depth case analysis of Hebei Province and proposes a design scheme for China's new energy incentive policy. The proposed scheme provides valuable reference for the formulation of China's 15th Five-Year Plan.

title: A Fault Detection Method for 5G Core Networks Based on Graph Attention Networks
authors: Han Yang, Ke Yu, Yongqing Zhu
publish: 2025 9th IEEE International Conference on Network Intelligence and Digital Content (IC-NIDC)
abstract: The increasing complexity and massive data volume of 5G core networks (5GC) bring significant challenges for timely and accurate fault detection, which is crucial to ensuring network reliability and user experience. However, existing methods often fail to effectively model the intricate spatiotemporal dependencies among multivariate Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) across different network elements, leading to limited generalization and poor detection robustness. In this paper, we propose GFD-5G, a Graph-enhanced Fault Detection model designed for 5GC. The model leverages a hierarchical Graph Attention Network (GAT) framework to capture correlations across element, time, and feature dimensions. A forecasting branch based on fully connected layers predicts future KPI values, while a reconstruction branch based on a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) models historical behavior. Moreover, a Peaks Over Threshold (POT)-based statistical module is introduced to automatically determine dynamic detection thresholds. The results verify the effectiveness and practical applicability of our approach in the maintenance of 5G networks.

title: Service Quality of Indonesian Customs Information and Automation System Version 4.0 and Stakeholders' Satisfaction-A Mediation Analysis
authors: Damar Aji Irawan, Rianto Nurcahyo, Tiurida Lily Anita, Dito Haekal Bagaskoro
publish: 2025 International Conference on ICT for Smart Society (ICISS)
abstract: This research aims to analyze the mediating effect of export customer-oriented training and relative service quality on the relationships between service quality (SERVQUAL) dimensions of Indonesian customs information and automation system version 4.0 (CEISA 4.0) and freight forwarders (FF) and customs service's companies' satisfaction. There has been limited analysis in the past studies regarding CEISA 4.0, service quality, and FF and customs service's companies' satisfaction. This research adopts a quantitative research approach using a cross-sectional survey to collect primary data from 153 respondents. The collected data is analyzed using PLS-SEM to examine the structural relationships and mediation effects in the research model. The results showed that export customer-oriented training fully mediates the relationship between service quality and satisfaction while relative service quality does not.

title: UCapsNet: A Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Breast Cancer Classification
authors: L.K. Sravanthi Potti, S. Maruthuperumal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Computing, Information and Control Systems (ICOIICS)
abstract: The present research resolves the deficiencies of traditional methods by presenting an improved U-Net model combined with a Capsule Network (referred to as UCapsNet). This technique uses more filters and skips connections to improve segmentation, while the capsule network uses dynamic routing to preserve spatial hierarchies to improve classification. In the proposed model robust approach for breast cancer segmentation and classification using the CBIS-DDSIM dataset is presented. The proposed methodology employs the Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) algorithm for clustering and segmenting breast cancer, followed by feature extraction through a combined convolutional neural network (CNN) + UNET model. These extracted features are then classified using Capsule-Net algorithms to identify images as benign or malignant, achieving an accuracy exceeding 96% on test data. The system is implemented as a web application comprising several modules. Users can upload the dataset, preprocess images, and extract features via FCM and CNN+UNET. The features are split into training and testing sets, where Capsule-Net algorithms are applied for model training and accuracy evaluation. Additionally, the application allows users to classify new test images, enhancing its practical utility for early breast cancer detection. It is observed by the proposed model that it has superior performance compared to state-of-the-art techniques such as CNN. Capsule-Net gives better performance than state-of-the-art techniques, which is shown using the Jaccard similarity score and dice score with metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F-score used for performance analysis. A confusion matrix is used for showing the colorful visualization of the difference between correct and wrong predictions.

title: SplitFedEE: Balancing Communication and Accuracy
authors: Erika Duriakova, Diarmuid O’Reilly-Morgan, Elias Tragos, Neil Hurley, Aonghus Lawlor
publish: 2025 International Conference on Visual Communications and Image Processing (VCIP)
abstract: SplitFed algorithm is a novel collaborative learning framework that enables decentralised learning of large deep architectures without the need to share sensitive raw data. However, this approach comes with a drawback of large communication overhead, as both the intermediate weights for forward propagation and gradients for backpropagation need to be regularly communicated with the server.This paper presents an empirical evaluation of methods that have the potential to address the communication inefficiency of the SplitFed algorithm. In particular, we study Early Exit (EE) algorithms and their application in the context of SplitFed. In our empirical evaluation, we insert the EE at the last layer of the local client model and train this smaller model locally in tandem with the large model. We show that the communication overhead can be reduced even further by randomly sampling smaller subsets from the training set. We evaluate this approach on several deep model architectures across various datasets and demonstrate that this approach can significantly save on communication while maintaining the accuracy of the base model.

title: One-Shot Masked Face Identification via Contrastive Representations
authors: Anjali T, Masilamani V
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology (CICT)
abstract: The degradation in the performance of the face recognition models after the regular usage of face masks due to viral infections such as COVID-19 leads to the importance of the research in occluded face recognition. This challenge is further worsened in real-world applications by the lack of large-scale labeled training data, making single-sample face recognition a particularly difficult task. In this paper, we propose a self-supervised learning based method to tackle the masked face recognition with single sample per identity. The proposed method uses a two stage training strategy. In the first step,a contrastive learning framework is employed to learn discriminative feature representations by contrasting positive pairs (different augmentations of the same identity) against negative pairs (different identities). In the second stage, the learned representations are used to extract embeddings, which are subsequently classified using a lightweight supervised classifier. Experiments demonstrate that our self-supervised learning approach significantly enhances feature discrimination, leading to improved classification accuracy in downstream masked face recognition tasks. The experiment results confirm that contrastive learning is a key enabler in building resilient face recognition systems for constrained scenarios such as masked or partially occluded face inputs.

title: A Multimodal and Real-Time Approach for Low-Resource Language Emotion Recognition
authors: Emmanuel M. J., Pranav Seelam, Mrithulasree N., Sankar Raja S., Siva Sankar P., Shoba S., Krithiga R., Satya Vankayala
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology (CICT)
abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, allowing systems to comprehend and react more effectively to users. Majority of emotion recognition models are developed using high-resource languages, hence constraining their efficacy for speakers of low-resource languages. This work uses a real-time multimodal emotion identification framework designed for low-resource languages for audio and visual features. The main objective is to incorporate deep learning-driven feature fusion approaches to improve emotion classification precision while mitigating the lack of labeled datasets via transfer learning and self-supervised learning. The real-time dataset created, named Tamil-Telugu Audio-Visual Speech Emotion Recognition (TTAVSER), has been tested with the deep learning models for audio-visual and demonstrated the results with different datasets and for low-resource languages of tamil and Telugu. The experimental findings of the model with real-time dataset attain significant accuracy with the state-of-the-art comparison with other low-resource languages.

title: Research on Evaluation Method of Power Regulation Capability of Urban Industrial Loads
authors: Yucheng Ding, Guanglong Xie, Xiaoling Jin, Yibo Jiang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: In the context of constructing a new power system dominated by renewable energy, this paper addresses the core issue of discrepancies between theoretical assessments and practical realities in industrial load regulation capability. It proposes a city-level assessment method for industrial load power regulation capability. This method overcomes the limitations of traditional algebraic superposition by establishing a time-resolved analytical model that integrates real-time load fluctuations and historical operational features to accurately quantify the regulation potential of a single user. It innovatively introduces a confidence assessment mechanism using the dual parameters of user response willingness and communication reliability to effectively address the problem of uncertainty in industrial user response. The simulation case, based on a 6 -node network, validates the practicality of the model. It systematically reveals the regulation capacity of urban-scale industrial loads. This work provides a scientifically quantified basis for power grids to accurately tap into demand-side adjustable resources and enhance the accommodation of renewable energy. It holds significant engineering application value for alleviating power supplydemand tensions and promoting synergistic source-load interaction.

title: Resource-Aware Dual-Granularity Synchronization Strategy for Transportation Digital Twin
authors: Yutong Wu, Xiaoyan Huang, Xiwen Liao, Ke Zhang, Supeng Leng
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) are essential to smart city development, yet traditional control frameworks struggle to meet the demands of complex scenarios such as autonomous driving. Digital Twin (DT) technology emerges as a powerful solution by enabling virtual representations of physical entities to support real-time state estimation, predictive analysis, and coordinated decision-making. However, existing research often underestimates the high cost of DT synchronization and migration, and lacks coordinated update strategies across vehicles and road segments. To address these challenges, we propose a dual-granularity DT construction scheme that jointly optimizes synchronization strategies for both vehicles and road segments, while coordinating communication and computational resource allocation. We formulate a joint optimization problem that integrates vehicle DT deployment, adaptive road segment DT updating, and resource scheduling. This problem is decomposed into two interdependent subproblems, which are solved using a hybrid algorithm that combines heterogeneous agent proximal policy optimization (HAPPO) and block coordinate descent (BCD). Simulation results demonstrate that our scheme significantly enhances DT quality while reducing overall system costs.

title: Frequency-Aware Native Resolution Assessment of 8K Omnidirectional Images
authors: Jingwen Hou, Zengliang Li, Jiebin Yan, Weide Liu, Yuming Fang, Wei Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Visual Communications and Image Processing (VCIP)
abstract: Omnidirectional images (ODIs) serve as fundamental visual medium for presenting virtual reality (VR) contents, supporting fully immersive experiences through 360-degree scene representation. Typically, a high pixel density is essential for visual quality in VR environments, which in turn requires sufficiently high-resolution imagery to achieve. However, capturing native high-resolution ODIs requires expensive omnidirectional cameras with large sensors (e.g., Insta360 TITAN). An alternative approach is to use low-resolution cameras to acquire original images and then enhance their resolution via super-resolution algorithms. In this work, we explore whether super-resolution ODIs can be easily distinguished from native high-resolution ODIs at 8K scale. To this end, we firstly construct the Native Resolution Assessment of 8K Omnidirectional Images (NRA- 8KODI) dataset, whose native 8K ODIs are collected with an Insta360 TITAN camera and 8K super-resolution images are generated from SOTA open-sourced algorithms. Recognizing high-frequency signals are essential for differentiating non-native 8K ODIs, a frequency-aware model is designed to capture high-frequency details. Specially, to maintain high-frequency details kept in high-resolutions while reduce computational costs brought by high-resolutions, we propose a frequency-aware compressor module to suppress feature channels dominated by low-frequency details. Finally, our model achieves 97.2% accuracy in detecting non-native 8K ODIs, implying that super-resolution for ODIs can still be improved for visual experience in VR applications.

title: PV Module Handling and Installation Car Based on Visual Recognition
authors: Qihang Liu, Chengbin Ye, Guobin Wei, Yongpei Tang, Peimei Xie, Mengyao Ou, Yunxiao Jin, Yongshi Lu, Bixing Xiao, Rong Dai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Low Carbon and Smart Energy (ICLCSE)
abstract: Aiming at the pain points of low efficiency and high labor intensity in the handling and installation of photovoltaic panels in the construction of photovoltaic power plants and module production, this study developed a set of autonomous handling and installation vehicles based on visual recognition. The car adopts Mecanum wheel omni-directional mobile chassis, and integrates the maixcam platform equipped with anchorbasedet visual recognition model and opencv algorithm, which can realize the accurate positioning of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$60 \text{mm} \times 90 \text{mm}$</tex> photovoltaic panels. Through the cooperative control of the 5 DOF serial bus servo manipulator and the four suction cups pneumatic suction system, the car can complete the gentle suction, handling and installation of photovoltaic panels. After 100 simulation experiments, the installation success rate is 95%, and the repeated positioning accuracy of the manipulator end is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1$</tex> cm. The results show that the suction handling mechanism significantly reduces the physical damage of the photovoltaic panel in the operation process, effectively improves the installation efficiency and positioning accuracy, provides a reliable technical scheme for the automatic processing of photovoltaic modules, and has the potential to replace the traditional manual operation.

title: Transformer-Driven Spatio-Temporal Modeling for Explainable Traffic Accident Hotspot Forecasting
authors: N. Giridharan M.E, Sandhiya P, Durga S, Shalini J K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Computing, Information and Control Systems (ICOIICS)
abstract: Traffic accidents remain a continuous issue within the sphere of the urban environment, affecting the safety and mobility of both people and communities. The ability to accurately understand where traffic accidents may occur can assist authorities with preventative measures and improved management of the road system. This study investigates the spatio-temporal modeling of accident data in order to understand the relationships of location and time, along with external factors, to the occurrence of a traffic accident. By applying a spatial relationship across the road network and a temporal relationship based on traffic flow, weather, and other events, the proposed methodology identifies riskier locations with more confidence and trustworthiness. The importance of explainability in decision making for policy-makers, planning, and transportation is preserved which allows utilizing information on road accidents to enhance safety and reduce risk, especially for vulnerable road users. The experimental analysis shows hotspot detection is reliable across a variety of traffic scenarios. Results from the study help to understand the extent that spatio-temporal features help to reduce uncertainty of prediction. Findings can assist to provide improved safety for road infrastructure planning or targeted approaches planned specifically for intervention. This study has presented a structured method of creating safer roads and reducing risk of accidents.

title: SkipSymNet: Skip-Connected Symmetric Network for Robust Small-Sample NIR Spectroscopy
authors: Hao Wang, Zhipeng Su, Chunbo Zou, Xiaoqiang Lu
publish: 2026 6th International Conference on Consumer Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICCECE)
abstract: Accurate quantification of biochemical components, such as protein content in agricultural products, via near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy is often hindered by the scarcity of labeled samples. Under small-sample conditions, models confront three intertwined bottlenecks: aliasing of key absorption features caused by strong spectral coupling between components, prediction instability introduced by instrument noise and sample state variations, and the consequent decline in model discriminability and generalization capability. To systematically address these challenges, this paper proposes a Skip-Connected Symmetric Network (SkipSymNet), whose core innovation lies in the synergistic integration of physics-guided feature engineering and a skip-connected symmetric neural architecture. First, we introduce a feature engineering pipeline based on prior knowledge of spectral-protein correlations, extracting rich statistical and morphological features from predefined physicochemical absorption regions to explicitly enhance input representation and interpretability. Second, we design a symmetric encoder-decoder network as the core predictor. Equipped with bidirectional information flow and hierarchical skip connections, it simultaneously preserves low-level spectral details and high-level contextual features, thereby improving training stability under small-sample conditions. Experiments conducted on a public wheat protein NIR dataset demonstrate that SkipSymNet consistently outperforms classical chemometric methods and representative deep learning baselines.
