Compared with the best-performing baseline method OMP-BVS, SkipSymNet increased R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> from 0.9438 to 0.9536 and reduced RMSE from 0.4125 to 0.3750 on an independent test set, achieving relative improvements of 1.03% in R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and 9.1% in RMSE reduction. These quantitative results validate that, by integrating domain-specific priors with a robust network structure, SkipSymNet offers a high-precision and highly robust solution for small-sample NIR spectroscopic analysis.

title: Attention-Enhanced Computer-Aided Diagnosis System for Accurate Classification of Brain Tumor
authors: Kalpanadevi R, Vemu Harshini, Sunkanaboina Chandra Lingamaiah, Priyanka Kokil
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology (CICT)
abstract: Brain tumors are difficult to detect and classify accurately because their shape, size, and appearance can vary widely in MRI scans. Early and precise identification is extremely important for planning treatment and improving patient outcomes. However, manually examining magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) requires a lot of time and expertise, which can increase the chances of error. To overcome these limitations, this work presents an automatic diagnosis system for brain-tumor classification. The proposed model uses a transfer learning approach to extract meaningful features of MRI images using the EfficientNetV2-B0. To strengthen these MRI cues, an attention model is incorporated in the baseline model, and later, the enhanced feature map is passed to the softmax layer through a pooling layer for final classification. The proposed model is validated on a brain tumor image dataset, which includes cases such as Glioma, Meningioma, Pituitary Tumor, and No Tumor. The validation results show that the proposed framework achieves the best accuracy and outperforms traditional deep learning models.

title: Fall Detection Based on Radar Sensor with Point Cloud Data using Pointnet-Based Deep Learning
authors: Nurya Fahru Rosyidin, Fiky Y. Suratman, Khilda Afifah
publish: 2025 International Conference on ICT for Smart Society (ICISS)
abstract: Human Activity Recognition (HAR) is an essential study area focused on identifying activities, especially in elderly care, where fall detection is vital for preventing serious injuries. millimeter-wave radar sensors represent a non-contact and privacy-preserving alternative to traditional sensors. This study attempts to create a radar-based fall detection system that uses 3D point cloud data and a deep learning approach based on PointNet. The primary focus is to address challenges such as limited dataset size, noise, and fluctuations in the number of points at each timestamp. These challenges are addressed through a pre-processing pipeline that includes augmentation, noise cleaning (ADBSCAN), data standardization (Moving Block Bootstrap), and temporal segmentation (sliding window). Classification is performed using the PointNet architecture, which directly processes point clouds. Based on testing results, the system achieved an accuracy of 99.97 %, with 0 False Positives and 2 False Negatives. Recall was 100% for ‘not_fall’ and 99.80% for ‘fall’. This excellent performance, especially the high recall across classes and zero False Positives, demonstrates the system's reliability and significant potential for accurate, non-intrusive elderly fall detection.

title: Smart Book Recommendation System with Item-Based Collaborative Filtering to Improve Resource Discovery: A Case Study in Bandung Library
authors: Wildan Fauzan Ramdana, Sinung Suakanto, Rachmawati, Ahmad Musnansyah, Safara Cathasa Riverinda Rijadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on ICT for Smart Society (ICISS)
abstract: The increasing digitization of library services has not always been accompanied by intelligent features that support personalized access to resources. Many community libraries still rely on static catalogs and keyword-based searches, which often fail to guide users efficiently toward relevant reading materials. This gap highlights the need for smarter, data-driven solutions to enhance book discovery and user engagement. This study aims to develop and integrate a web-based book recommendation system for a community library using item-based collaborative filtering. The system leverages historical borrowing data to compute item similarities, allowing for personalized suggestions in two main scenarios: when users view a specific book and when accessing the dashboard. The development follows the Design Science Research (DSR) methodology, encompassing problem identification, system design, implementation, demonstration, and evaluation. The recommendation model was evaluated using Precision@K and Recall@K metrics, with results showing high precision for small recommendation sets (e.g., Precision@3 = 0.9412) and improved recall as the number of recommendations increased (e.g., Recall@10 = 0.8415). These findings suggest that the model achieves a practical balance between relevance and breadth. The study concludes that item-based collaborative filtering is an effective approach for enhancing book discovery in library settings. The system contributes to the development of intelligent digital infrastructure in community libraries, supporting more personalized and engaging user experiences.

title: LLM for Telecom Fraud SMS Annotation & Classification: Integrating RAG and Multimodal Knowledge Enhancement
authors: Wenhao Liu, Zhe Han, Xuan Peng, Lan Yang, YuJia Sun
publish: 2025 9th IEEE International Conference on Network Intelligence and Digital Content (IC-NIDC)
abstract: To combat the growing threat of telecom fraud, we propose an LLM-based SMS classification system tailored to real-world scenarios from China Unicom. By constructing a 17-category labeled dataset and integrating Deepseek-R1 with a multiround prompt strategy, we achieve high-accuracy semantic understanding and classification of sensitive SMS content. In addition, we improve performance through RAG-based retrieval, rule-based detection, and a structured database system. Our approach demonstrates both technical innovation and deployment feasibility for large-scale antifraud applications.

title: Artificial Neural Network Technique for Non-Latin Ancient Manuscripts' Character Recognition
authors: Setiawan Hadi, Mira Suryani, Shofiyyah Nadhiroh, Sukono
publish: 2025 International Conference on ICT for Smart Society (ICISS)
abstract: Artificial Neural Networks are becoming popular and can be implemented in multidisciplinary research, including research related to cultural heritage. This paper aims to implement artificial intelligence methods to recognize ancient Sundanese characters in the lontar manuscript images using Faster Region Convolutional Neural Network (Faster R-CNN). The dataset used is the Lontar manuscript images provided by the AMADI project, which include information about the class name and coordinate points. The method consists of two main modules. The first module is Region Proposal Networks, which produces region proposals. At the same time, the second module is Fast R-CNN as a detector. This method uses VGG-16 as a convolutional layer. This study conducted two types of experiments based on the anchor ratios used. The first experiment uses a single type of anchor ratio, while the second experiment uses three different types. Experimental results showed that the model using three different anchor ratios has a higher accuracy value than the others, at 77%, and can recognize syllables in a full Sundanese manuscript image with promising results.

title: Deep Neural Networks for Automated Detection of Arrhythmia and Coronary Artery Disease
authors: Hasan Fayyad-Kazan, Ismaeel Al Ridhawi, Ali Abbas
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on ICT &amp; Accessibility (ICTA) co-located with 2025 2nd International Conference and Forum on Assistive Technologies for Special Needs (ATSN)
abstract: Medical services are under pressure to provide prompt access to accurate diagnostic techniques due to the significant number of cardiovascular disease-related deaths that occur globally. Clinical practitioners use electrocardiography (ECG) for cardiac abnormality detection. However, clinician interpretation leads to inconsistent results and delayed medical decisions. This paper introduces an Artificial Intelligence (AI) system which analyzes ECG data to identify arrhythmias and diagnose Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). A one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) was developed to identify arrhythmias while a fully connected network served for CAD prediction. The models reached 96.2 % accuracy in arrhythmia detection and 92 % accuracy in CAD binary prediction after training on multiple benchmark datasets with advanced preprocessing and augmentation methods. The models were integrated into a cloud-based E-hospital platform to provide real-time analysis, electronic medical record (EMR) connectivity, and remote access capabilities. The proposed system demonstrated that Deep Learning (DL) improves medical accuracy while decreasing physician workloads and making cardiac care available to more patients in areas with limited resources.

title: A CFD Analysis on the Cornerfill Encapsulation Process in BGA Package Subjected to Varying Dispensing Paths
authors: Fei Chong Ng, ZiJing Yu, Yangming Liu, Bo Yang, Ning Ye
abstract: Underfill encapsulation is commonly used to enhance the reliability of flip-chip and ball grid array (BGA) in electronic package assembly. However, prolonged filling, incomplete filling and void formation remain significant challenges of the capillary underfill process in the packaging industry. Apart from the conventional single dispensing inlet (Itype), double dispensing inlets (L-type) and triple dispensing inlets (U-type), this paper explores the feasibility of cornerfill to achieve desired filling coverage and within a reasonably short filling time. The underfilling process of a BGA package subjected to dispensing at corners is numerically simulated using ANSYS Fluent. Four different cornerfill dispensing paths are studied: 2 mm for both short and long sides, 1 mm (short side) +3 mm (long side), 3 mm (short side) +1 mm (long side) and corner dot dispensing. Qualitative comparison of the ANSYS Fluent simulated filling coverages of BGA package with the experimental cross section and Moldex3D simulated findings at the end of corner fill process show good agreement to each other. It is found that the asymmetrical dispensing with 3 mm path at the long side of package yield highest filling coverage of 71%; while having a longer dispensing path at the short side of the package gave a relative uniform flow front. The dot dispensing at the corner, however, yields a qualitatively similar filling profile as the symmetry dispensing path. This study showed that the filling rate and coverage of cornerfill process are dependent on the dispensing path. As a generalization, the package side that is perpendicular to the direction of least ball rows (i.e. the long side of the package) should be subjected with a longer dispensing path.

title: Adaptive Inertia Forecasting via Quantile Regression and KDE–GPD Fusion
authors: Keqiang Yin, Muyang Liu, Genzhu Wu, Peiyi Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: With increasing renewable penetration, system inertia becomes highly time-varying and uncertain, challenging frequency stability. This paper proposes a day-ahead probabilistic inertia forecasting method integrating Quantile Regression (QR), Kernel Density Estimation (KDE), and Generalized Pareto Distribution (GPD). QR captures the conditional backbone of inertia, KDE smooths residuals, and GPD models extreme tails. A distributional calibration mechanism ensures reliable coverage of prediction intervals. Using historical UK power system data, the proposed QR–KDE–GPD fusion model outperforms benchmarks in both probabilistic metrics (CRPS, PICP, PIT) and deterministic errors (MAPE, RMSE), providing accurate, well-calibrated forecasts for frequency-security assessment in renewable-rich systems.

title: On Optimal Energy Efficiency in Low-Rate Wireless Personal Area Networks
authors: Anshan Yuan, Xinghua Sun, Wen Zhan, Yaru Fu, Xiang Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: Characterizing and optimizing energy efficiency in Carrier Sense Multiple Access (CSMA)-based Low-Rate Wireless Personal Area Networks (LR-WPANs) remains challenging due to varying power consumption levels and sporadic data transmission. To address this issue, this paper focuses on the analysis of energy efficiency in CSMA-based LR-WPANs. Specifically, by considering finite energy, varying power consumption, and network throughput, we derive the closed-form expressions for lifetime throughput and achieve optimal energy efficiency by tuning the access probability. The analysis indicates that when data traffic is sporadic, the optimal channel access probability aligns with the right endpoint of the unsaturated region. Maintaining the access probability at this optimal point significantly minimizes energy wastage, balances network throughput, and reduces contention. These findings provide valuable insights into the configuration of access parameters for achieving high energy efficiency in CSMA-based LR-WPANs.

title: Parametric Analysis of Diamond-based Lateral Heat Extraction in 3D Heterogeneous Electronic Systems
authors: Bin He, Yong Han, Huicheng Feng, Gongyue Tang
abstract: As 3D heterogeneous chip integration advances beyond Moore's Law scaling limitations, thermal management becomes increasingly critical due to blocked heat dissipation pathways in stacked architectures. This paper presents a novel diamond-based lateral heat extraction approach utilizing diamond interlayers with extended edges to create accessible thermal interfaces for external cooling systems. Comprehensive finite element simulations examine two configurations: foursided diamond extensions that achieve <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> temperature reduction compared to single-sided configurations under 20 W power dissipation, and cost-optimized single-sided designs for simplified packaging. Parametric analysis reveals optimal diamond dimensions of 20 mm width and 0.15 mm thickness, providing excellent thermal-to-cost ratios. Material comparison demonstrates diamond's superior performance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2000 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{K}$</tex> thermal conductivity) achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 - 1 4}{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> lower temperatures than silicon carbide and aluminum nitride alternatives, and even with through-diamond-via integration reducing effective thermal conductivity to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$700 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{K}$</tex>, diamond configurations maintain <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> performance advantage. This approach enables higher power density operation in next-generation heterogeneous systems while providing practical design guidelines for processor architectures, HBM integration, and AI accelerators across multiple market segments.

title: Interfacial Reactions of BiIn and SnBi Solders React with Cu Substrate
authors: Yi-Wun Wang, Tzu-Yi Lin, Jang-Cheng Fang, Kai-Lin Cheng, Xiang-Ting Lin
abstract: BiIn and SnBi solders are getting increasingly important due to their low-melting point. With a lower melting point compared to traditional SnAgCu or SnAg solders, it reduces thermal budget on components and enhances energy efficiency. However, there are still some challenges, such as mechanical strength concerns, rework difficulties, limited alloy options, that need to be overcome. Despite several drawbacks that impact reliability and performance, ongoing study is improving low-temperature solder properties. It is without question that low-temperature solder is a key factor for sustainability and advanced packaging. Bi33In, Bi48In and Sn56Bi2Au are carried out in this study. The results show interfacial microstructure of the reactions of Bi33In, Bi48In and Sn56Bi2Au react with Cu. The important results are as follows: (1) Discontinuous intermetallic compounds formed in the reaction between Bi33In and Cu after reflow; (2) Discontinuous <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cu}_{11} \text{In}_{9}$</tex> and two phases <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cu}_{11} \text{In}_{9}+\text{In}$</tex> formed in the reaction between Bi48In and Cu after aging; (3) Indium content affected the wettability significantly; (4) Au addition to SnBi improves joint strength; (5) Bulk-type AuSn 4 has larger hardness than needle-type AuSn<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>.

title: Priority-Aware Drone Scheduling Using Multi-Armed Bandits with Upper Confidence Bound
authors: K.Harshitha, G. Sanshrey Reddy, Preeth Raguraman, S Raghavan
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology (CICT)
abstract: The scheduling of drones plays a vital role for low latency data collection and decision making in a cyber-physical system. The priority-aware alert management system for drones operating in dynamic environments using the Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB) framework is proposed in this paper, enhanced with the Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) strategy. In this setup, four drones operate sequentially in four defined time slots per day, each receiving a predefined amount of battery at the start of the day. The system aims to intelligently allocate drone resources to process one alert per drone per slot. This is taken into consideration as drones have limited onboard processing power, communication bandwidth, and payload capacity. Each alert requires flight maneuvers, sensing, and data transmission, that works based on learned priorities from task types. Alerts are queued in a buffer and can expire based on their priority cycle. The system uses MAB-UCB to maximize its reward for each selection. In this paper, the results of the MAB-UCB approach is compared with the traditional algorithms, that showcases significant improvements in selection policy. The simulation study also reveals a systemic processing bottleneck, a key finding which highlights that even an optimal agent is constrained by system capacity. Furthermore, the results shows that the agent successfully identifies high-risk geographical zones and critical time windows. It also demonstrates the ability of the presented work to uncover valuable operational intelligence from raw alert data.

title: Chip Stacking: Impact of Chip Spacing in C2W Hybrid Bonding on Temporary Bonding and Debonding
authors: Jaibir Sharma, Dileep Kumar Mishra, Vasarla Nagendra Sekhar, Bhesetti Chandra Rao
abstract: The Temporary Bonding and Debonding (TBDB) process plays a pivotal role in 2.5D/3.0 D integration for thin and fragile wafers to be securely supported during aggressive backend processing steps such as thinning, through-silicon via (TSV) formation, and interconnect creation. In 2.5D integration usually multiple dies are mounted on an interposer with different pitch (spacing), and in 3.0D stacking vertical integration through TSVs is employed with certain pitch (spacing between chips or stacks). Temporary bonding materials must exhibit strong adhesion during hightemperature and high-stress processes, yet allow clean, residuefree debonding under control conditions (mechanical, thermal slide, laser release, or chemical methods). This paper explores the impact of chip spacing on the outcome of temporary bonding and debonding (TBDB) processes for chip to wafer (C2W) hybrid bonding integration. Debonding and cleaning modules were optimized using 0.5mm, 1.0 mm and 10.2 mm spaced chips bonded wafer. Results demonstrate that the spacing between chips significantly influences the effectiveness of final debonding and the successful removal of glue residues, highlighting a critical factor for optimized 3D integration.

title: Carousel: A High-Resolution Dataset for Multi-Target Automatic Image Cropping
authors: Rafe Loya, Andrew Hamara, Benjamin Estell, Benjamin Kilpatrick, Andrew C. Freeman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Visual Communications and Image Processing (VCIP)
abstract: Automatic image cropping is a method for maximizing the human-perceived quality of cropped regions in photographs. Although several works have proposed techniques for producing singular crops, little work has addressed the problem of producing multiple, distinct crops with aesthetic appeal. In this paper, we motivate the problem with a discussion on modern social media applications, introduce a dataset of 277 relevant images and human labels, and evaluate the efficacy of several single-crop models with an image partitioning algorithm as a pre-processing step. The dataset is available at https://github.com/RafeLoya/carousel.

title: Digital Twin and AI-Driven Data Augmentation for Defect Identification in Renewable Energy Equipment
authors: Qionglan Na, Peng Zang, Xin Li, Hongyan Jia, Yifei Wang, Yixi Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: The rapid expansion of renewable energy installations has introduced unprecedented challenges in equipment fault diagnosis, particularly the scarcity of high-quality labeled fault samples required for training accurate diagnostic models. This paper proposes a comprehensive framework integrating digital twin simulation and generative AI algorithms to address data insufficiency in renewable energy equipment defect identification. First, a novel data augmentation method combining TimeGAN (Time-series Generative Adversarial Network) and t-SNE (t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding) is developed to enhance both the quantity and diversity of defect samples, achieving a sample diversity coefficient improvement from 23.7% to 89.6%. Second, a multi-physics digital twin model integrating aerodynamic, mechanical, and electrical subsystems is constructed to simulate high-fidelity fault data across multiple failure modes including short circuits, open circuits, overvoltage, and vibration anomalies. Third, a Stacking ensemble learning model is proposed to leverage the complementary strengths of multiple intelligent algorithms, enhancing robustness and high-dimensional data processing capability. The proposed defect identification model achieves an average accuracy of 94.0%, representing a significant improvement over the baseline accuracy of 92.3%. Finally, an intelligent operation and maintenance solution integrating a knowledge base and intelligent search functionality is implemented to provide refined equipment maintenance guidance. Field deployment demonstrates a 68.7% reduction in annual average unplanned outages compared to industry benchmarks, validating the practical effectiveness of the proposed framework in large-scale renewable energy operations.

title: Optimizing Voting Ensemble Strategies for Classifying Student Anxiety Levels Based on Narrative DAAS Responses
authors: Pandu Pratama Putra, Sarjon Defit, Gunadi Widi Nurcahyo
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd Student Conference on Research and Development (SCOReD)
abstract: This study aims to measure the anxiety levels of students in Indonesia using a machine learning approach applied to narrative data collected from DAAS questionnaires completed by students at Universitas Lancang Kuning. The developed workflow includes data cleaning, case folding, stemming, feature extraction using Term Frequency Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF), and class balancing on the training data using Synthetic Minority Over Sampling Technique (SMOTE). Three base models were evaluated: Random Forest, C4.5, and Naive Bayes. These models were then combined using two ensemble strategies, Hard Voting and Soft Voting. The classification task involved five levels of anxiety: Normal, Mild, Moderate, Severe, and Very Severe. The evaluation used accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score, and confusion matrix. Results showed that C4.5 achieved the best baseline performance with approximately 87% accuracy, followed by Random Forest and Naive Bayes, each with around 83% accuracy. The use of ensemble methods consistently improved classification performance. Soft Voting reached an accuracy of 0.88 with macro precision, recall, and F1 score each at 0.88. Meanwhile, Hard Voting achieved the highest performance with 0.89 accuracy, 0.90 macro precision, 0.89 recall, and 0.89 F1 score. The confusion matrix analysis indicated that the Severe and Very Severe classes were classified accurately, while the Moderate class remained the most challenging to distinguish, often overlapping with Mild or Normal. These findings confirm that voting-based ensemble strategies are effective for narrative-based anxiety classification and can serve as a reliable method for early mental health screening in academic environments.

title: Multiclass Classification of Skin Lesions from Imbalanced Dataset A Comparative Analysis of Pretrained Transfer Learning Models
authors: Tazwar Mahmud, Md Rezanur Rahman, Tanmoy Mondal, Md. Anikur Rahaman, Md Shohel Rana, Md Maruf Hasan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Computing, Information and Control Systems (ICOIICS)
abstract: Correct and precise identification of skin lesions is of great importance for the early recognition and proper treatment of melanoma and other skin diseases. The present research makes use of advanced deep learning methods in the classification of skin lesions based on the ISIC 2019 dataset, which is made up of 25,331 dermoscopic pictures representing eight diagnostic categories. To improve the performance of the model and to deal with the class imbalance issue, extensive preprocessing procedures such as image resizing, normalization, and data augmentation were carried out on the images. The dataset was divided into three parts: training (80 %), validation (10 %), and testing (10 %) to allow for a stringent model evaluation. Three prominent pre-trained convolutional neural network architectures-MobileNetV2, Xception, and DenseNet-were implemented and fine-tuned using Adam and RMSprop optimization algorithms. Among these, MobileNetV2 exhibited superior classification performance, attaining an initial accuracy of 96 %, subsequently enhanced to 99 % through systematic hyperparameter tuning. The close alignment between training and validation accuracies suggests effective mitigation of overfitting and underfitting. This investigation advances AI-based dermatological diagnostics by evidencing the capability of deep learning models to manage imbalanced datasets and achieve high classification accuracy, thereby contributing to more reliable and efficient clinical decision support systems.

title: Capacity Planning Strategy for Photovoltaic-Storage-Charging Integrated Stations Considering Sourceload Uncertainty and Battery Aging Characteristics
authors: Dali Huang, Shangkang Lin, Xiaobing Su, Ying Wang, Chenmu Li, Tao Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: With the accelerating global energy transition, photovoltaic-storage-charging integrated stations (PVSCIS) have emerged as a key solution for enhancing renewable energy utilization and facilitating the low-carbon transformation of the transportation sector. However, the capacity planning of PVSCIS is challenged by the randomness of photovoltaic generation, variability in electric vehicle charging demand, and degradation of energy storage systems. Ignoring these factors may result in suboptimal capacity configurations, leading to resource inefficiencies and supply inadequacies. This paper proposes a capacity planning model for PVSCIS that accounts for source-load uncertainty and battery aging effects. A stochastic scenario generation method, combining Monte-Carlo simulation with backward synchronous iteration, is employed to characterize the source-load uncertainty. Comparative simulations under different energy storage modeling strategies and uncertainty conditions validate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed approach. Results indicate that incorporating battery degradation mechanisms and source-load uncertainty into the investment optimization process significantly improves system robustness and stabilizes lifecycle economic performance, providing valuable insights for the sustainable deployment of integrated energy systems.

title: Design for Testability for VLSI Circuits with A Large Number of Unknown Test Response Sources
authors: Dong Xiang, Wenfei Wang, Can Xiang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Test Conference in Asia (ITC-Asia)
abstract: A new test compression scheme is proposed by using a new DFT architecture, a new gating technique, and a new low-power test application scheme for circuits with a large number of unknown test response sources. A probabilistic measure is proposed to analyze the potential of scan flip-flops to capture unknown responses. All scan flip-flops with enough potential to capture unknown test responses are clustered to localize the effect of the unknown sources on fault coverage. A new test response compactor is presented to avoid unknown test responses and minimize fault coverage loss in the software-defined linear feedback shift-register (SLFSR) based test compression environment. Experimental results are presented to show the effectiveness of the new method.

title: Joint Recommendation and Inventory Optimization in Cross-Border E-Commerce via Multimodal PinSAGE and SAC
authors: Jia Li, Yan Sun, Lirong Li, Bi Ye, Heung Kou
publish: 2026 6th International Conference on Consumer Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICCECE)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of cross-border e-commerce (CBEC), catalyzed by frameworks such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), has fundamentally reshaped the global trade landscape, introducing unprecedented market opportunities alongside profound operational complexities. This paradigm shift is characterized by non-stationary demand environments where consumer preferences exhibit high volatility, logistics chains are elongated and stochastic, and the coupling between demand generation and supply fulfillment remains historically brittle. Traditional decision-making paradigms often treat consumer recommendation and inventory control as decoupled silos, leading to suboptimal outcomes such as the simultaneous occurrence of stockouts for high-velocity items and the obsolescence of long-tail inventory. This research proposes a novel, closed-loop supply-demand collaborative mechanism designed to navigate these complexities. On the demand side, we construct a high-precision user profiling system utilizing a Multimodal PinSAGE architecture. This incorporates DistilBERT for semantic extraction from multilingual product descriptions and EfficientNet for high-fidelity visual feature learning, fused via a random-walk-based graph convolutional network to capture complex, high-order user-item interactions. On the supply side, we develop a Multi-Objective Soft Actor-Critic (MO-SAC) reinforcement learning agent responsible for dynamic inventory optimization. This agent operates within an entropy-regularized framework to balance exploration and exploitation amidst demand volatility, optimizing for profit maximization, service level maintenance, and holding cost minimization simultaneously. By mathematically coupling these subsystems, the framework enables a real-time synchronization where recommendation algorithms actively promote stockavailable items to shape demand, while inventory policies proactively adjust replenishment orders based on aggregated algorithmic engagement signals. Extensive empirical experiments on the Amazon-M2 and Taobao User Behavior datasets demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving superior Recall@10 and NDCG@10 metrics while reducing total inventory costs by approximately 29% under simulated RCEP logistics conditions.

title: Enhancing Wafer Bonding Strength Via Surface and Dielectric Modification Using Plasma Activation Process
authors: Jaehyung Park, Jihun Kim, Junghan Lee, Myeonggon Jang, Junhong Min, Sohye Cho, Hyewon Ji, Jintae Park, Joohee Jang, Sekho Kim, Dongchan Lim, Sungho Lee, Hojin Lee, Seunghun Lee, Sangjin Hyun
abstract: This study systematically investigates the mechanisms by which plasma treatment modes influence wafer bonding strength in Silicon Carbon Nitride (SiCN) dielectrics. Both Remote and Reactive Ion Etching (RIE) O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> plasma treatments were applied, and their effects on surface chemistry, subsurface modifications, and bulk moisture interactions were evaluated using TEM, ToF-SIMS, XPS, and MEIS analyses. RIE plasma treatments were found to progressively increase bonding strength with longer exposure times, due to subsurface ion-induced damage that facilitates water uptake and subsequent silanol-to-siloxane conversion. In contrast, Remote plasma treatments promote surface hydroxylation, enhancing initial bonding strength, but extended exposure reduces bonding efficacy by diminishing surface -OH density. Incorporation of low-k layers beneath the bonding dielectric further improves bonding strength by enabling controlled moisture absorption and enhancing siloxane network formation, particularly in thinner and more porous upper dielectric layers. Dense dielectrics limit this effect due to restricted water diffusion. These results reveal a complex interplay between surface chemistry, plasma-induced subsurface modifications, and bulk moisture properties, offering actionable insights for the design of dielectric stacks and plasma activation strategies to achieve mechanically robust W 2 W and D 2 W bonds.

title: Attentive Routing: Feasible Routing via Communication-Aware Attention in LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Xiujie Wang, Lizhe Liu, Bin Wang, Jianwei Li, Yuxiang Hu, Dongdong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: The rapid development of Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite networks has elicited demand for intelligent routing solutions to balance traffic loads and enhance quality of service (QoS). However, constrained by the inability to systematically collect and process routing information for building supervised training databases, most existing methods rely on reinforcement learning approaches that assume a fixed number of satellites and a stable training environment, which need to reset state space and retrain model when encountering contingencies such as satellite failures. To improve the generalization capability of satellite routing, this paper innovatively proposes a structured approach for processing satellite communication information and a framework for feasible routing in LEO constellations via communicationaware attention, named Attentive Routing. This framework structurally encodes communication information, employs a communication-aware attention encoder to extract topological communication hotspot patterns, and utilizes a feasible satellite routing decoder to directly generate routing paths across different LEO topologies. For dynamic satellite quantity changes, we design multilevel embedding and positional encoding to serialize satellite topology and communication quality metrics into model inputs. Performance refinement is achieved through Reinforcement Learning from Environment (RLE), which continuously fine-tunes Attentive Routing using feedback from OMNeT++ simulations. Extensive evaluations demonstrate its capability to generate adaptive paths across varying satellite network topologies, which increases total throughput by approximately 5.5 %, reduces average end-to-end delay by at least 20 %, and improves bandwidth satisfaction by 27.5 %, all while maintaining an exceptionally low packet loss rate.

title: Timing Estimation for Deep Space Optical Communication Signals
authors: Bin Wang, Xiaoyan Wang, Yuning Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: The deep space optical systems use the frames of pulse position modulation (PPM) of M slots and the inter-symbol guard times (ISGT) of P slots, and also use a single-photon-counting detector array on the flight terminal to detect the uplink optical signal at photon-starved (pW/m^2) power levels. An estimation method of timing offsets for the M PPM and P ISGT frame format, named ISGT timing offset estimation method, is proposed in this article. The timing information carried by the PPM and ISGT frames is extracted for demodulation and decoding. This method provides synchronization without using the data bandwidth compared with the pilot method, as well as eliminating or reducing the effect of the Earth and ambient background illumination. The algorithm of the ISGT timing offset estimation method is analyzed and the statistical modeling is implemented in the co-simulation of OptiSystem and MATLAB software. The feasibility of this method is proved by the simulation results.

title: An Improved K-means Algorithm based on Density-Weighted Canopy for Typical Wind Power Scenario Extraction
authors: Dongliang Nan, Jian Ma, Yinzhang Peng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: The stochastic nature of wind power poses challenges to power system planning. Accurate extraction of typical wind power scenarios is fundamental for optimizing energy storage and ensuring grid stability. While K-means is widely used, its performance is highly dependent on the pre-determined cluster number and random initial centroids, often leading to sub-optimal results. Furthermore, pre-clustering algorithms like Canopy rely on subjectively defined thresholds. To address these limitations, this paper proposes an improved K-means algorithm based on a density-weighted Canopy (DWC-Kmeans). This method introduces a density-weighting mechanism to automatically identify high-density data points as initial cluster centers. This approach adaptively determines the optimal cluster number and initial centroids, circumventing the arbitrary threshold settings. The proposed algorithm is validated using one year of measured output data from a 30MW wind farm. The clustering performance is quantitatively evaluated using the Silhouette Coefficient, Sum of Squared Errors, and the Davies-Bouldin Index. Results demonstrate that the proposed DWC-Kmeans algorithm significantly outperforms both the traditional K-means and the standard Canopy-Kmeans algorithms across all three metrics. The method provides an accurate, stable, and objective approach for extracting wind power scenarios, offering a robust data foundation for power system planning.

title: Entropy-Guided Active Learning Framework with Hybrid Acoustic and Deep Self-Supervised Features for Dysarthria Detection
authors: Vishwas Yeleshwaram, Sanjay Sayam, Y C A Padmanabha Reddy, Viswanath Pulabaigari
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology (CICT)
abstract: Dysarthria is a neurological speech disorder characterized by a lack of clarity and intelligibility in speech due to damaged nervous systems. Although promising results have been achieved with automated detection methods, progress is limited due to the scarcity of labeled data and significant variability in speech patterns from speaker to speaker. In this paper, we present an active learning-powered data-efficient framework for dysarthria detection. Our approach avoids direct labeling efforts on large datasets; instead, the system repeatedly selects a batch of the samples it is most uncertain about and asks only for their annotation. Starting with a small labeled set, the model is gradually improved by adding high-uncertainty examples from a larger unlabeled pool, reducing the labeling effort while boosting accuracy. Our experiments show that this uncertainty-guided strategy can indeed yield strong performance with far fewer labeled samples, taking a practical step toward scalable and clinically usable dysarthria detection tools.

title: FRGDM: Pre- to Post-Contrast Medical Image Synthesis Based on Diffusion Models
authors: Shijian Chen, Chunlin He, Fuyou Fan, Yi Liu, Xinxiang Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Data Science and Intelligent Systems (DSIS)
abstract: Medical imaging offers essential insights into internal anatomical structures and disease progression. Contrast agents are commonly used to enhance image quality and improve diagnostic accuracy, but they may impose significant renal burdens, especially in patients with impaired kidney function. Diffusion models (DMs) have recently shown strong performance in medical image translation. However, conventional DMs rely on static guidance from the source image and often lose critical structural details during the forward diffusion, which are hard to fully recover. This limitation can result in anatomical distortion and diagnostic errors. We propose a Frequency-guided Recursive Diffusion Bridge Model (FRDBM) to address this issue. Unlike standard DMs, FRDBM defines the diffusion path between the source and target images and incorporates frequency-domain information to preserve structural fidelity. Our approach enables the generation of contrast-enhanced images from non-contrast ones, potentially avoiding the use of contrast agents. Experiments on MRI contrast enhancement demonstrate that FRDBM achieves state-of-the-art performance in preserving fine-grained anatomical details and diagnostic image quality, with quantitative metrics (PSNR: 29.775 dB on BraTs; SSIM: 0.917) surpassing all competing methods.

title: Transfer Learning Enabled Human Imaging in RIS-Aided Communication Systems
authors: Ruijie Fan, Yixuan Huang, Zhou He, Jie Yang, Shi Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
abstract: Advances in mobile communication technology promote the development of integrated sensing and communication, where imaging is anticipated to be realized within communication systems. This motivates the need for improved wireless imaging techniques. Traditional compressed sensing and fourier transform imaging methods face the problems of unknown sparsity of the region of interest and requiring a large number of pilot signals. Although artificial intelligence based imaging methods in previous studies can partially solve these issues, they typically require large amounts of training data, which is hard to be obtained in wireless imaging scenarios. To address these challenges, we propose a new imaging method using transfer learning (TL). Specifically, we first train the neural network (NN) on a large synthetic dataset and fine-tune it using a small number of human images. We respectively employ a multilayer perceptron (MLP), a convolutional NN (CNN), and a U-NET to realize human imaging, where their performances are extensively compared. Simulation results reveal that our proposed method can achieve effective imaging of human body based on limited training data, even when considering multipath interference. We find CNNs exhibit better TL performance compared to MLPs.

title: Mesh-Based Planning for Distribution Networks Considering the Risk of Voltage Imbalance
authors: Xin Yang, Ran Xu, Fan Zhou, Tiancheng Shi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on New Energy and Power Engineering (ICNEPE)
abstract: The distributed access with single-phase and uncertain generation of renewable energy increases the risk of voltage unbalance limit violations in distribution network. With the increasing penetration of renewable energy generation, it is important to study how to mitigate the impacts of intermittent renewable energy generation on the risk of voltage unbalance limit violation in distribution network. This paper proposes a shared energy storage allocation strategy and optimal operation method based on global sensitivity analysis (GSA). First, a back propagation neural network (BPNN) based probabilistic voltage unbalance factor calculation model for distribution network is constructed, and the risk index of distribution network probabilistic voltage unbalance factor limit violation is defined. It can quickly and accurately quantify the impacts of uncertain renewable energy generation on the risk of voltage unbalance limit violation in distribution network. Then, a GSA method based on Wasserstein distance is proposed to identify the critical renewable energy sources affecting distribution network voltage unbalance. Finally, the GSA-based shared energy storage allocation strategy and the rolling prediction optimization-based operation method of shared energy storage are proposed. Simulation results on the IEEE 123-bus system demonstrate that the proposed framework reduces the maximum probabilistic voltage unbalance exceedance risk by over 74 % compared to the case without energy storage. The rolling optimization operation effectively smooths renewable power fluctuations, validating the practical efficacy of the method in enhancing distribution network security. The effectiveness of the proposed methods is verified through the simulation analysis of IEEE 123 bus distribution network.

title: Real-Time Anomaly Detection of Advanced Persistent Threats Using Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: S. Satheeshkumar, P. T. Kalaivaani, V. Lathika, Hema S J, K. Karthick, R. Rajalakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Computing, Information and Control Systems (ICOIICS)
abstract: Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) pose a serious risk to modern digital systems because of their stealthy and multi-stage nature, which allows them to slip past traditional security defenses. This study introduces a real-time anomaly detection framework based on Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to accurately identify APT activities throughout their attack lifecycle. Unlike conventional detection models, the proposed system continuously learns normal network behavior and flags unusual patterns linked to reconnaissance, lateral movement, data theft, and initial compromise. A custom-built dataset capturing different APT behaviors, along with associated tactics, techniques, and indicators of compromise (IoCs), was used for model training and testing. The GAN design features a generator that replicates normal network traffic and a discriminator that identifies malicious deviations in real time. Through this adversarial learning process, the model effectively recognizes complex patterns and distinguishes between legitimate and suspicious activities. Experimental evaluations show that the model delivers high accuracy in detecting subtle and evolving APT attacks. By enabling real-time monitoring and full-stage threat coverage, this approach provides a reliable and scalable solution for proactive cybersecurity defense.

title: On the Natural Frequency of a Coriolis Vibration Gyroscope with a Cylindrical Resonator
authors: Vadym Avrutov, Serhii Golovach, Hryhorii Strokach, Viacheslav Tsisarz, Oleksii Petrenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Methods and Systems of Navigation and Motion Control (MSNMC)
abstract: The eigenfrequencies of the Coriolis Vibrational Gyroscope with cylindrical resonator and their influence on the output signal of the gyroscope are considered. The obtained formulas for calculating the eigenfrequencies of CVG with a metal cylindrical resonator have been experimentally confirmed in practice by the acoustic method. The results of spectral analysis of a single impact on the resonator showed the splitting of the resonant frequency into two components with peaks of 5781.05 Hz and 5787.53 Hz. The non-ideal geometry of the cylinder causes this splitting. The results of the experimental study on the real split resonant frequency and Q-factor demonstrate the importance of considering the non-ideal resonator for the accuracy of modeling its dynamic characteristics. The results of modeling the movement of the CVG are presented, which demonstrate a significant impact on the characteristics of the oscillating system not only of the different frequencies, but also of its phases relative to the excitation axis X and the measurement axis Y. Assessment of the influence of multi-frequency on the properties of the CVG as an angular velocity sensor indicates the possibility of using this influence in the CVG control system. It is demonstrated that the use of the CVG control system in scanning mode for multi-frequency resonator characteristics has found practical application in CVG balancing operations, specifically in identifying and removing unbalanced resonator masses.
